title.narrative: Using Sniffer Dogs to Combat Trafficking in Saiga Horn in Kazakhstan

description.narrative: This project makes a direct contribution to the conservation of the critically endangered saiga antelope, and other threatened species including the saker falcon, snow leopard and steppe tortoise. Specifically, the purpose of the project is to counter illegal wildlife trafficking of saiga horn and other products in Kazakhstan by training and deploying sniffer dog teams to detect trafficked wildlife products. Specific activities include (1) the sourcing, training and certification of eight dogs and handlers to detect saiga and following scoping other species; (2) developing and monitoring a strategic deployment plan for dog teams, and convening high-level Kazakh officials to improve co-ordination and prioritization of wildlife crime by key agencies; (3) providing in-depth and practical CITES training to on-the-ground Kazakh enforcement staff, through a 4-day workshop for 30 staff and a detailed regulations manual and identification guide.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Using Sniffer Dogs to Combat Trafficking in Saiga Horn in Kazakhstan

description.narrative: This project makes a direct contribution to the conservation of the critically endangered saiga antelope, and other threatened species including the saker falcon, snow leopard and steppe tortoise. Specifically, the purpose of the project is to counter illegal wildlife trafficking of saiga horn and other products in Kazakhstan by training and deploying sniffer dog teams to detect trafficked wildlife products. Specific activities include (1) the sourcing, training and certification of eight dogs and handlers to detect saiga and following scoping other species; (2) developing and monitoring a strategic deployment plan for dog teams, and convening high-level Kazakh officials to improve co-ordination and prioritization of wildlife crime by key agencies; (3) providing in-depth and practical CITES training to on-the-ground Kazakh enforcement staff, through a 4-day workshop for 30 staff and a detailed regulations manual and identification guide.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Strengthening Capacity and Collaboration to Combat Trafficking in Saiga Horn in Kazakhstan

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to counter the trafficking of wildlife products in Kazakhstan and specifically to conserve the Critically Endangered saiga antelope (Saiga tatarica tatarica) by addressing the impacts of poaching and the illegal trade in saiga horn and derivatives. Specific activities will include: (1) investigating and mapping saiga horn trade routes and establishing protocols for collation and sharing of such dynamic information between enforcement agencies; (2) promoting and improving the use and coordination of strategic, intelligence-led anti-poaching patrolling and sniffer dog deployment, resulting in more effective enforcement; (3) strengthening anti-poaching by introducing new approaches such as SMART and building practical wildlife crime investigation skills to create a stronger evidence base for prosecutions; (4) promoting advocacy in the judiciary for the prosecution of wildlife crime; and (5) promoting improved standards in the use of sniffer dogs to detect illegally trafficked saiga horn and other wildlife products and cooperation with nascent sniffer dog programs in two neighboring transit countries.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Strengthening Capacity and Collaboration to Combat Trafficking in Saiga Horn in Kazakhstan

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to counter the trafficking of wildlife products in Kazakhstan and specifically to conserve the Critically Endangered saiga antelope (Saiga tatarica tatarica) by addressing the impacts of poaching and the illegal trade in saiga horn and derivatives. Specific activities will include: (1) investigating and mapping saiga horn trade routes and establishing protocols for collation and sharing of such dynamic information between enforcement agencies; (2) promoting and improving the use and coordination of strategic, intelligence-led anti-poaching patrolling and sniffer dog deployment, resulting in more effective enforcement; (3) strengthening anti-poaching by introducing new approaches such as SMART and building practical wildlife crime investigation skills to create a stronger evidence base for prosecutions; (4) promoting advocacy in the judiciary for the prosecution of wildlife crime; and (5) promoting improved standards in the use of sniffer dogs to detect illegally trafficked saiga horn and other wildlife products and cooperation with nascent sniffer dog programs in two neighboring transit countries.

Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Agency for International Development, Development Assistance

title.narrative: COMBATING TRAFFICKING OF CRITICALLY ENDANGERED SAIGA ANTELOPE IN KAZAKHSTAN

description.narrative: (1) strategic redeployment of active sniffer dogs and police, and the introduction of an additional 10 sniffer dogs along identified trade routes and hotspots; (2) support for innovative technologies, including drones and camera traps, to improve monitoring effectiveness across the vast Ustyurt plateau; (3) strengthening ranger capacity using SMART and applying measures to ensure appropriate ranger health and safety; (4) data gathering of local socio-economic and cultural factors to advance understanding of the drivers for poaching; (5) a comprehensive training program for law enforcement agencies; (6) implementation of inter-agency data management and seizure protocols for wildlife trafficking; (7) analysis of trafficked wildlife products and development of consistent identification methods; and (8) support to convene neighboring countries towards a more coordinated transboundary response to wildlife crime. This proposal has been informed by learning gained from previous USFWS-funded activities (2016-2019).

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: COMBATING TRAFFICKING OF CRITICALLY ENDANGERED SAIGA ANTELOPE IN KAZAKHSTAN

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to counter the trafficking of wildlife products in Kazakhstan and to conserve the critically endangered saiga antelope (Saiga tatarica) with a focus on the Ustyurt saiga population. The project will address the poaching of saiga and trafficking in saiga horn and derivatives, which is becoming more sophisticated and adaptive to law enforcement responses. Specific activities of this two-year grant include: (1) strategic redeployment of active sniffer dogs and police, and the introduction of an additional 10 sniffer dogs along identified trade routes and hotspots; (2) support for innovative technologies, including drones and camera traps, to improve monitoring effectiveness across the vast Ustyurt plateau; (3) strengthening ranger capacity using SMART and applying measures to ensure appropriate ranger health and safety; (4) data gathering of local socio-economic and cultural factors to advance understanding of the drivers for poaching; (5) a comprehensive training program for law enforcement agencies; (6) implementation of inter-agency data management and seizure protocols for wildlife trafficking; (7) analysis of trafficked wildlife products and development of consistent identification methods; and (8) support to convene neighboring countries towards a more coordinated transboundary response to wildlife crime. This proposal has been informed by learning gained from previous USFWS-funded activities (2016-2019).

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

title.narrative: COMBATING TRAFFICKING OF CRITICALLY ENDANGERED SAIGA ANTELOPE IN KAZAKHSTAN

description.narrative: Funds under this award are to be used for: (1) strategic redeployment of active sniffer dogs and police, and the introduction of an additional 10 sniffer dogs along identified trade routes and hotspots; (2) support for innovative technologies, including drones and camera traps, to improve monitoring effectiveness across the vast Ustyurt plateau; (3) strengthening ranger capacity using SMART and applying measures to ensure appropriate ranger health and safety; (4) data gathering of local socio-economic and cultural factors to advance understanding of the drivers for poaching; (5) a comprehensive training program for law enforcement agencies; (6) implementation of inter-agency data management and seizure protocols for wildlife trafficking; (7) analysis of trafficked wildlife products and development of consistent identification methods; and (8) support to convene neighboring countries towards a more coordinated transboundary response to wildlife crime.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: BUILDING A COLLABORATIVE FOUNDATION FOR EVIDENCE-BASED SAIGA ANTELOPE CONSERVATION

description.narrative: THE USFWS SPECIES CONSERVATION CATALYST FUND IS A UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY TO BUILD BOTH A SYSTEMIC UNDERSTANDING OF THE DRIVERS AND LEVERAGE POINTS FOR SAIGA USE AND TRADE, AND TO BUILD A FOUNDATION FOR LONG-TERM COLLABORATIVE NETWORKS TO IMPLEMENT, AND ADAPTIVELY MANAGE, CONSERVATION ACTIONS. THIS WILL WORK BEST IF ALL THE STAKEHOLDERS COLLABORATE TOGETHER TO ENSURE THAT THEY MAXIMISE OPPORTUNITIES FOR SYNERGY AND LEARNING ACROSS COUNTRIES, STAGES IN THE SUPPLY CHAIN, AND STAKEHOLDER TYPES. FUNDING FOR SPECIES CONSERVATION IS OFTEN DISPERSED ON A PROJECT-BY-PROJECT BASIS, AND AWARDEES FOCUS ON FULFILLING THEIR OWN AIMS AND MEETING THEIR DELIVERABLES - THEREBY LOSING THE OPPORTUNITY TO ENGAGE ACROSS PROJECTS, AND TO LEARN FROM EACH OTHER. ADDITIONALLY, SHORT-TERM PROJECT FUNDING CAN LEAD TO EXCELLENT RESULTS BUT NEW EVIDENCE CAN BE KEPT WITHIN THE TEAM ITSELF, SO OPPORTUNITIES ARE LOST TO USE IT AS A FOUNDATION FOR ONGOING LEARNING AND EVIDENCE-GENERATION BY THE BROADER CONSERVATION COMMUNITY. FINALLY, INVESTMENT IN CAPACITY-BUILDING FOR TEAM MEMBERS IS VITAL. HOWEVER, OPPORTUNITIES TO EXTEND THIS INVESTMENT BEYOND THE PROJECT TEAM TO SUPPORT PEOPLE IN OTHER COUNTRIES, SECTORS, AND PARTS OF THE SUPPLY CHAIN, ARE NOT ALWAYS GRASPED - THEREBY LIMITING THE EXTENT OF ITS IMPACT. THERE S AN OPPORTUNITY TO DO THINGS DIFFER

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry
